job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Columbus, OH
pros: Supervisor and manager were really caring and listened to the staff concerns. A very homely environment
cons: Low pay but they do give yearly bonuses

review_title: Good Benefits, But Can Sometimes Get Burnt Out
job_title: Direct Support Personnel in Westerville, OH
pros: I had a great manager and supervisor who would listen to concerns as I had a client with a behavior plan and who ran off at least eight other DSPs. There's also a lot of opportunities for overtime and the insurance was GREAT. I had a $500 deductible and $3000 out of pocket max and it was about $50 a week for a single person. I would still be there if it wasn't for having to relocate to another city.
cons: Some of the clients with behavioral plans can be difficult and sometimes, they are super short-handed and it can be easy to feel burnt out. The pay isn't terrible, but not excellent.

pros: Meaningful work, helping others is one of the top benefits of working at Hattie Larlham. Seeing our individuals happy and thriving is an amazing perk of the job. In addition, I'm happy that I have a flexible schedule, generous PTO, affordable health insurance, great pay, and an awesome team to work with.
cons: It's tough working in the healthcare industry right now due to low staffing. COVID hit this field hard. Current staff are picking up the slack to ensure our individuals continue to receive proper care. Like other healthcare and I/DD facilities, we need more compassionate and caring people who want a rewarding career helping others. Advice to new hires - your workdays aren't always going to be easy but stick it out and commit to your role - the grass isn't always greener on the other side, which is why we regularly have previous employees come back to continue providing services to our persons served.

pros: Staff & the supervisors work together. The supervisors & nurses step in to help.
cons: Sometimes overwhelming with amount to do with short staffing.

job_title: Office Support Staff in Mantua, OH
pros: I have been with Hatties for almost 10 years. Juet like most places, it has its days, but I really enjoy coming to work. My job as an office staff member Is pretty ideal. I use to work floor support aswell full time, the people who live in our facilities will change your outlook on so many things. Hatties is a really fun place to work with the right mindset.
cons: Staffing is always an issue,but thats everywhere.

review_title: Overall, a Great Place to Work!
pros: Flexible schedule Good vacation time Departments work well together Residents are great! Opportunity to develop working relationships with a variety of clinicians. Opportunity to work with a unique population in improve in a variety of treatment skills/knowledge.
cons: Pay below industry standard (secondary to non-profit status) Paper documentation (mostly)

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Akron, OH
pros: The persons served, co workers.
cons: Scheduling is inconsistent at times.

pros: The Art Tracker position is extremely rewarding and fun. The art studio is the only place where the individual's served are in full control. Once you learn to communicate with them you will form a strong bond and grow attached. It is one of the few stable positions available for those with an art degree. There is also a lot of freedom in how you want to organize your sessions, schedule, and studio.
cons: The pay can be on the lower side. There is a high turnover in DSP staff. Overall the work environment is negative despite their efforts to boost morale.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Westerville, OH
pros: Team spirit, great individuals, flexibility
cons: Some staff don’t like to cook or clean.

pros: Great place to work. Overall rewarding job.
cons: Not many cons. Great place to work.

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Akron, OH
pros: Good pay, Flexible, overtime available always
cons: They don't care about their employees

pros: Good, caring managers. Employee appreciation is pretty decent. Helpful co-workers.
cons: Short staffed most of the time. Overworked managers/staff. Low pay, low raises.

pros: It is a great place to work
cons: I have no issues or concerns

pros: Working with the residents is the best part. Great benefits, fun culture
cons: Non-profit salaries aren’t great, fewer options for growth

review_title: I have worked at Hattie's for 4 Years currently just went PRN
pros: Love the individuals. They are the best part about the job. They are so sweet & innocent. The trips. My management I had in the group home was the best. No complaints about the management there. You can make a lot of money due to overtime because there are always openings within the different homes. It's had it great days.
cons: Working at Main Campus is the worst choice. I would say going to the group homes are what's best if you want to keep your job. The pay could be 100% better due to how much hard back labor you do. Their medical, Dental, & vision plans suck completely. You have to pay for everything. They don't want their employers to smoke like its Cleveland Clinic or University Hospital or something. As much stuff you put up with they you need smoke a cigarette or four. Their payroll SUCKS !!! My check was messed up once a month. I recently resigned from my full time position & I had vacation to be paid out. They are dragging along paying my money like I didn't work for it. They don't appreciate their workers as much as they should. They give you a $35 honey baked ham certificate for the holidays as a bonus. I felt like a Slave within the company because they do what they want & work you to death & if they could they wouldn't pay you.

pros: We are doing a job that makes a huge difference in the lives of so many individuals.  We help suceed in things most would feel they are unable to even do let alone do well.
cons: If you are a manager or PC your job will always come first.  You are sometimes put in a postion that requires you work 100 hours a week and when you question that you are told it is your responsibility.

pros: Everyone is so kind and caring, the residents are wonderful, great benefits, overall just a great atmosphere!
cons: Wages could be a little better, but I know they are working on it!

review_title: Satisfaction Depends on Who Supervises You
pros: Flexibility, teamwork, mission, clients, volunteers
cons: Constant staffing turnover on residential care units, permanent "Now Hiring" signs posted out by the road of main campus, administrative staff and middle managers seem stressed, depressed, and generally unhappy.

review_title: Rewarding work, great people, typical non-profit pay
pros: Working for the Hattie Larlham foundation is a reward experience in which you meet great people and help wonderful people with disabilities achieve social and economical goals.
cons: As is common with non-profit organizations the pay is not that great and it can be difficult to find advancement in the company.

review_title: The CEO and Board President need to go
pros: Co-workers, residents (Mantua center), resident activities, a few managers that truly care about their staff. The individuals served are the reason many of us are here.
cons: Oh, where to begin? Administration has become secretive as it plans for a new "Hattie" that would have the real Hattie rolling in her grave. They've lost site, in large part because CEO seems determined to make changes that are negative for the people we serve. "Benefits" are worthless - if you can even get them. The majority of staff are less than 28 hours/week in order to avoid providing insurance. They actually hold sessions for uninsured staff on how to get Medicaid/free insurance and food stamps. Um, Walmart anyone?

pros: Programs are based on helping those who need assistance and serve both people and the community at large.
cons: Terrible management. There are people in administration that are there to serve themselves and not truly there to help anyone but themselves.

pros:
*benefits if fulltime (I wasn’t) 
*can get a lot of overtime 
*clients are awesome 
*pretty laidback depending on the house you’re at (as a DSP) 
* get paid CPR/First Aid and Med Passing (some places will pay new employees hundreds of dollars for having these , wink wink)
cons:
* some clients are difficult to deal with 
* far travels sometimes 
* low pay 
* lack of communication between coworkers and management 
* often asked to work a lot of hours

pros: You get to work with DD individuals and make an impact on their lives through meaningful activities and connections to the community.
cons: Low pay and mixed messages from management. Non-flexible schedules and no break time to decompress during the day.  High risk of being falsely accused.

pros: 1. The residents are wonderful to provide care for.
cons:
1. The management is horrible. 
2. There is bullying that takes place on the Main campus.
3. Some of the supervisors are very unprofessional and allow their staff to deliberately disrespect and mistreat other employees.

pros: I get paid to talk to people. The atmosphere is laid back. The people there really care.
cons: The pay is not very good for what I do.

pros: Having the privilege of serving the DD Community for a number of years
cons: Little to no room for advancement, large amount of staff turn-over, dwindled attention to the details of care provided the individuals served in comparison of when Hattie was alive and actively apart of the decision making

review_title: Good mission Poor ethics and culture
pros: The mission of the organization and the opportunity to help people with disabilities gain vocational training.
cons:
Extreme cliques
Lack of Ethics!!! 
Poor management 
Lies against employees 
Lack of connections between departments
Poor employee training or continuous learning programs
Very low compensation except at the very top

pros: The individuals make the job worth it.
cons: raises are horrible, understaffed constantly, work is back braking, and there is lots of gossip and tension between employees. Turn over rate is horrible.

review_title: It is a great place to work

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Akron, OH
